title: export all unicode helper functions

labels.name: AutoMerge
labels.description: Causes a PR to be automatically merged once all requirements are passed.

body:
We were exporting these functions via .def files instead of dllexport.

Update to use the macro and some vcxproj changes for desktop to reduce warnings about duplicate functions in unit/integration tests.

I did not use the API_() form since that changes the calling convention, which might be fine but is slightly annoying for copy in a dll ABI compat

title: RNW adding new npm package breaks vs 2017 sln  and forces reinstall from scratch not .net but i cant delete the label
body:
### Environment

    System:
      OS: Windows 10
      CPU: (8) x64 Intel(R) Core(TM) i7-6700T CPU @ 2.80GHz
      Memory: 4.35 GB / 15.88 GB
    Binaries:

react-native: 0.58.0

 -  framework   10.0.14393,  

  Desktop, 
 
- Development Operating System: windows 10
 
- Visual Studio Version: 2017 community

 
- Build Configuration: Debug

### Steps to Reproduce
 

1.Start with an installed version of react-native for windows
2.try to add any new npm package (npm i -s *)  (and package will do 
3.  try and rebuild solution under visual studio 17

### Expected Behavior
 
no errors 
 

### Actual Behavior

6>D:\ddesktop\rn\windows\rn\App.xaml.cs(24,25,24,40): error CS0433: The type 'ReactNativeHost' exists in both 'ReactNative.Net46, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null' and 'ReactNative, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'

6>D:\ddesktop\rn\windows\rn\App.xaml.cs(10,26,10,41): error CS0433: The type 'ReactNativeHost' exists in both 'ReactNative.Net46, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null' and 'ReactNative, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'
6>D:\ddesktop\rn\windows\rn\MainReactNativeHost.cs(25,33,25,46): error CS0433: The type 'IReactPackage' exists in both 'ReactNative.Net46, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null' and 'ReactNative, Version=1.0.0.0, Culture=neutral, PublicKeyToken=null'
6>D:\ddesktop\rn\windows\rn\MainReactNativeHost.cs(11,32,11,49): error CS0115: 'MainReactNativeHost.MainComponentName': no suitable method found to override
6>D:\ddesktop\rn\windows\rn\MainReactNativeHost.cs(14,30,14,49): error CS0115: 'MainReactNativeHost.UseDeveloperSupport': no suitable method found to override

6>D:\ddesktop\rn\windows\rn\MainReactNativeHost.cs(25,48,25,56): error CS0115: 'MainReactNativeHost.Packages': no suitable method found to override

 
Add Any npm package and it forces and entire rebuild from scratch of react-native for windows

 

### Reproducible Demo

 this is my package.json  

{

  "version": "0.0.1",

    "preset": "react-native"
  }
}

remove react-native-svg and install, react-native windows etc
it should run fine.

then try and add svg to it... it wont work.

This is true for any of the packages in the dependency  list.  

remove and add    "react-native-material-ui": "^1.30.1"

title: Updated Flyout to attach as ContextFlyout on Target
body:
We want to be able to implement a context menu in UWP. The Menu will be built as a Flyout on the application side, but we want to try and make use of the XAML contextFlyout property on UIElement.

Added a prop attachAsContextFlyout to the Flyout component, which when set to true attaches the flyout control to the target elements' contextFlyout property. This allows us to take advantage of built in XAML context actions (such as right click, keyboard shortcut etc.) without needing to add the functionality on the application react side.
This can eventually be used to make Context Menus similar to these example: 
[https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/uwp/design/controls-and-patterns/menus](url)
ContextFlyout reference: [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.ui.xaml.uielement.contextflyout#Windows_UI_Xaml_UIElement_ContextFlyout
](url)

![ContextFlyoutExample](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23387006/60846759-516fef00-a195-11e9-9087-ba91476da6c6.gif)


###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/2744)

title: Using TextInput in modal is broken
body:
Targeted Platform: UWP
Version:10.0.15063

VS Version: Visual Studio 2017

Issue:
1) Use TextInput component inside Modal
2) After launching modal, the TextInput automatically gets focus and remains the focused always. It doesn't blur on clicking anywhere else on the screen.

title: Addition of MenuFlyout for UWP
body:
Wrapped the following components with view managers:
MenuFlyout,
MenuFlyoutItem,
MenuFlyoutSubItem.

The menuFlyout component has a prop attachAsContextFlyout, which when set to true attaches the menu flyout control to the target elements contextFlyout property. This allows us to take advantage of built in XAML context actions (such as right click, keyboard shortcut etc.) without needing to add the functionality on the application react side.
This can be used to make Menus and Context Menus as shown: 
[https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/windows/uwp/design/controls-and-patterns/menus](url)

References:
MenuFlyout: [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.ui.xaml.controls.menuflyout](url)
ContextFlyout: [https://docs.microsoft.com/en-us/uwp/api/windows.ui.xaml.uielement.contextflyout#Windows_UI_Xaml_UIElement_ContextFlyout
](url)

Added an example to the Sample App to demonstrate basic functionality:
![MenuFlyoutExample](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23387006/60839950-3f855080-a183-11e9-9ebf-8f5d8287849e.gif)

Screenshots:
![menuFlyout_sub_menu](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23387006/60839966-4b711280-a183-11e9-9819-cbdced6e262c.png)
![menuFlyout_open](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23387006/60839968-4c09a900-a183-11e9-8d2f-e92b4ae87415.png)
![menuFlyout_right_aligned](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23387006/60839970-4c09a900-a183-11e9-8df1-816019f893f6.png)
![menuFlyout_simple](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/23387006/60839971-4c09a900-a183-11e9-825c-5c21b0497333.png)





###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/2738)

This fixes #1580 

I am not sure what the correct base branch is, feel free to name me another one if 0.57-stable was incorrect.

title: System.Runtime.interopServices.COMException 'An async operation was not properly started. Only a single ContentDialog can be open at a time
body:
react-native -v: 0.57.0
npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows: 0.2.9
npm ls react-native-windows: 0.57.1
node -v: v10.16.0
npm -v: 6.9.0

Issue Details:

I have one Modal from 'react-native'; and inside that i have many fields like, inputText, ModalDropDown.
Whenever i am clicking on dropdown i am getting error "System.Runtime.interopServices.COMException 'An async operation was not properly started. Only a single ContentDialog can be open at a time".

While if drop down is inside normal View then it is working fine.

title: Fix PropertyID comparison for Charkra based jsi::Runtimes.
body: PropertyID comparison for Charkra based jsi::Runtimes is completely broken right now and needs to be fixed.

title: Date Picker component changes for UWP
body:
The changes are based on an old PR https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/1881. The current PR adds only the DatePicker component and will add the TimePicker component as well based on the reviews from here. 

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/2599)

title: Omit CREATE_LAYOUT_THREAD definition for 'current'
body:
https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/issues/2066

Remove layouting thread for 'current' engine to avoid responsiveness issues.

###### Microsoft Reviewers: [Open in CodeFlow](http://wpcp.azurewebsites.net/CodeFlowProtocolProxy2.php?pullrequest=https://github.com/microsoft/react-native-windows/pull/2530)

title: Feature request: WebGL support
body:
Would love to see WebGL contexts being supported through this library. This would open the door for 3D apps to be built with JavaScript for Windows environments. It would be a huge win for libraries like Babylon and Three. 

I think that `react-native` itself doesnt yet support WebGL, but it would be an awesome feature to see Microsoft take charge of.

title: Windows project name to be generated from app.json instead of package.json
body:
### Environment

<!--
  Please fill in all the relevant fields by running these commands in terminal.
-->

1. `react-native -v`: 0.57.4
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`: 0.2.9
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`: 0.57.1
4. `node -v`: 8.12.0
5. `npm -v`: 6.4.1
6. `yarn --version`<!-- (if you use Yarn) -->:

Then, specify:

<!-- (What platform are you building for? Choose any from UWP, WPF) -->
- Target Platform: UWP

<!-- (What framework version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.14393, 10.0.10586, 10.0.10240, etc. (UWP), .NET 4.6.1, .NET 4.5, etc. (WPF) -->
- Target Platform Version(s): 10.0.14393

<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Mobile (ARM), Mobile Emulator, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s): Desktop, Mobile

<!-- Which operating system are you using? Specify macOS, Windows, or Linux, along with specific release versions -->
- Development Operating System: Windows 10.0.15063 Build 15063

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2017 -->
- Visual Studio Version: 2017

<!-- Which build configuration are you running? Choose from Debug, DebugBundle, Release, ReleaseBundle -->
- Build Configuration: Debug

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesnt know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->

React Native projects uses app.json file to specify the name and display name of the platform specific projects. Android and iOS platforms use this name. 

1. Run "react-native windows" on your project to add the platform.
2. Verify the project name created under windows folder.

### Expected Behavior

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  Its fine if youre not sure your understanding is correct.
  Just write down what you thought would happen.
-->

The project name and other related files should have used the name specified in app.json.

### Actual Behavior

<!--
  Did something go wrong?
  Is something broken, or not behaving as you expected?
  Describe this section in detail, and attach screenshots if possible.
  Don't just say "it doesn't work"!
-->

The name in the package.json file was used to generate the windows project which is a deviation from the expected react native behaviour. If the name mentioned in the package.json has a hypen (which is the case in most package names), the windows project throws an error as hyphen is not allowed in the name.  

<!--
  Please share a project that reproduces the issue.
  There are two ways to do it:

    * Create a new app using https://snack.expo.io/ and try to reproduce the issue in it.
      This is useful if you roughly know where the problem is, or cant share the real code.

    * Or, copy your app and remove things until youre left with the minimal reproducible demo.
      This is useful for finding the root cause. You may then optionally create a Snack.

  This is a good guide to creating bug demos: https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve
  Once youre done, copy and paste the link to the Snack or a public GitHub repository below:
-->

<!--
  What happens if you skip this step?

  Someone will read your bug report, and maybe will be able to help you,
  but its unlikely that it will get much attention from the team. Eventually,
  the issue will likely get closed in favor of issues that have reproducible demos.

  Please remember that:

    * Issues without reproducible demos have a very low priority.
    * The person fixing the bug would have to do that anyway. Please be respectful of their time.
    * You might figure out the issues yourself as you work on extracting it.

  Thanks for helping us help you!
-->

- Build Configuration: Not known

### Steps to Reproduce

I have run the command react-native windows. And get "Could not find react-native-windows@0.57.*."
I have tried with differentversion of react-native (0.56, 0.54) but still gets the issue. 

After running the command npm install --save-dev rnpm-plugin-windows, I realized that the package react-native-windows was not installed....And I manually installed it with npm install react-native-windows. Still the same error...

Would you have hints ?

Thanks.

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesnt know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->

(Write your steps here:)

1. Open index.windows.js from Playground.Net46. Import Image component.
2. Change the default code in render() to 

```
      <View style={styles.container}>
        <Text>
          React Native Windows!
          <Image source={{uri: 'https://facebook.github.io/react/logo-og.png'}}
       style={{width: 400, height: 400}} />
        </Text>
      </View>
```

3. Run Playground

### Expected Behavior

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  Its fine if youre not sure your understanding is correct.
  Just write down what you thought would happen.
-->

Errors should not be. We should see a picture in the text.

### Actual Behavior

<!--
  Did something go wrong?
  Is something broken, or not behaving as you expected?
  Describe this section in detail, and attach screenshots if possible.
  Don't just say "it doesn't work"!
-->

You will see:
```
Error Invariant Violation: requireNativeComponent: "RCTTextInlineImage" was not found in the UIManager.

This error is located at:
    in RCTTextInlineImage (at Image.windows.js:271)
    in ForwardRef(Image) (at Playground/index.windows.js:21)
    in RCTText (at Text.windows.js:189)
    in TouchableText (at Text.windows.js:322)
    in ForwardRef(Text) (at Playground/index.windows.js:19)
    in RCTView (at View.js:45)
    in View (at Playground/index.windows.js:18)
    in Playground (at renderApplication.js:34)
    in RCTView (at View.js:45)
    in View (at AppContainer.js:98)
    in RCTView (at View.js:45)
    in View (at AppContainer.js:115)
    in AppContainer (at renderApplication.js:33)
```

Looks like `Image.windows.js` was updated to use `RCTTextInlineImage`, but `RCTTextInlineImage` itself doesn't has it's UI Module in C#. This module is available for Android with class name: `FrescoBasedReactTextInlineImageViewManager`

### Reproducible Demo

<!--
  Please share a project that reproduces the issue.
  There are two ways to do it:

    * Create a new app using https://snack.expo.io/ and try to reproduce the issue in it.
      This is useful if you roughly know where the problem is, or cant share the real code.

    * Or, copy your app and remove things until youre left with the minimal reproducible demo.
      This is useful for finding the root cause. You may then optionally create a Snack.

  This is a good guide to creating bug demos: https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve
  Once youre done, copy and paste the link to the Snack or a public GitHub repository below:
-->

Reproduced on the latest [master](https://github.com/Microsoft/react-native-windows) also in UWP

<!--
  What happens if you skip this step?

  Someone will read your bug report, and maybe will be able to help you,
  but its unlikely that it will get much attention from the team. Eventually,
  the issue will likely get closed in favor of issues that have reproducible demos.

  Please remember that:

    * Issues without reproducible demos have a very low priority.
    * The person fixing the bug would have to do that anyway. Please be respectful of their time.
    * You might figure out the issues yourself as you work on extracting it.

  Thanks for helping us help you!
-->

title: #230 datepicker
body:
It's been a while since the first PR for #230. The project has changed its structure slightly and as such I thought it might be easier to just start anew. Here is the code with the changes suggested by @rozele. Here is a summary of the changes:

- Refactors the JS bridge components to comply with the new structure (uses ES6 classes instead of `React.createClass` and other minor changes).
- Removes the `DateTimePicker` element.

Based on the review from @rozele, some changes might still be missing:
- No support for WPF and no `NotImplementedException` handling. How should I approach that? Simply defining the component in the `ReactNative.Net46` project?
- Views still extends the `BaseViewManager` class instead of `SimpleViewManager`. The components I took as reference use `BaseViewManager`, so I kept it. With some reference I might be able to do the refactoring.

title: Bundle builds crash on Windows 7 (WPF) / Unable to build working WPF apps
body:
### Environment

1. `react-native -v`: 0.57.1
2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`: 0.2.8
3. `npm ls react-native-windows`: 0.57.1
4. `node -v`: 10.0.0
5. `npm -v`: 6.4.1
6. `yarn --version`: 1.7.0

Then, specify:

- Target Platform: WPF (Windows 7 SP1)
- Target Platform Version(s): .NET 4.6
- Target Device(s): Desktop
- Development Operating System: Windows 10 x64 1803
- Visual Studio Version: VS2017
- Build Configuration: DebugBundle + ReleaseBundle

### Steps to Reproduce

- react-native init `projectname`
- cd `projectname`
- yarn add react-native@0.57.1
- npm install --save-dev rnpm-plugin-windows
- npm install --save-dev rnpm-plugin-wpf
- react-native windows
- react-native WPF
- npm install --save-dev schedule@0.4.0
- [ open ./wpf/`projectname`.sln in VS2017 ]
- retarget solution to Win8.1
- `react-native bundle --platform windows --entry-file index.js --bundle-output wpf\projectname\ReactAssets\index.wpf.bundle --assets-dest wpf\projectname\ReactAssets`
- Build solution with 'ReleaseBundle' and x86
- Build solution with 'DebugBundle' and x86
- Create 'ReactAssets' folder in build output folder
- Copy 'index.wpf.bundle' created above into the 'ReactAssets' folder created in previous step (do this for both)
- Execute the DebugBundle/`projectname`.exe on Windows 7 SP1
- Execute the ReleaseBundle/`projectname`.exe on Windows 7 SP1

### Expected Behavior

The application should display the default 'Welcome to react native windows' template project created as part of `init` - this should happen for both DebugBundle and ReleaseBundle.

### Actual Behavior

When launching the executable of either build, an error occurs;

Debug bundle error (Windows 7);
![image](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/12896049/55355965-98c55000-54c1-11e9-8af2-bd5d3e2af53c.png)

LoadedModule[60]=C:\Windows\System32\nlaapi.dll
LoadedModule[61]=C:\Windows\System32\npmproxy.dll
LoadedModule[62]=C:\Windows\Microsoft.NET\Framework\v4.0.30319\diasymreader.dll
FriendlyEventName=Stopped working
ConsentKey=CLR20r3
AppName=projectname
AppPath=C:\Users\my_username\Desktop\ReleaseBundle\projectname.exe
`

The DLL filename that's not found is not present in the error dialog.

Both project launch without issue on the Windows 10 development machine.

If the `ReactAssets` and the bundle JS file are not present, the application closes a few seconds after the executable starts with no error reported.

### Reproducible Demo

Due to the sheer size of a reproducible project (400MB), it is simply not feasible to share. However, this package.json should provide some insight;

`{
  "name": "windows7demo",
  "version": "0.0.1",
  "private": true,
  "scripts": {
    "start": "node node_modules/react-native/local-cli/cli.js start",
    "test": "jest"
  },
  "dependencies": {
    "react": "16.8.3",
    "react-native": "0.57.1",
    "react-native-windows": "0.57.1"
  },
  "devDependencies": {
    "@babel/core": "^7.4.0",
    "@babel/runtime": "^7.4.2",
    "babel-jest": "^24.5.0",
    "jest": "^24.5.0",
    "metro-react-native-babel-preset": "^0.53.1",
    "react-test-renderer": "16.8.3",
    "rnpm-plugin-windows": "^0.2.8",
    "rnpm-plugin-wpf": "^0.1.2",
    "schedule": "0.4.0"
  },
  "jest": {
    "preset": "react-native"
  }
}
`

### Additional Notes

* The Schedule package was installed to prevent the bundler from complaining about it not being in the hasted map.
* The ReactAssets folder and JS bundle are added independently after build completes to prevent an issue where they are not bundled by default.
* React-native-windows works as expected but does not support Windows 7 from my research. If this is not correct, please advise of how to target Windows 7 / WPF without needing react-native-wpf.
* The Windows 7 install in question has .net framework 4.6.2 installed but other than that, is a fresh install.
* The project bundle folders have been copied to run from the local Windows 7 drive to prevent any network related issues (e.g. file resolution problems) before attempting to run them.

title: [Releases] Document react-native dependency versioning strategy
body:
We need to determine what approach we will take for taking a dependency on `react-native` in the master branch of our repo. Currently, we lock the master branch to a specific version of `react-native` but there are pros and cons to that approach.

**Pros:**
- Minimal reasoning required to cut a release that is compatible with a particular version of `react-native`.
- Batches breaking changes that we need to worry about.
- Lower overhead for updating dependencies. Tracking against master requires more frequent updates to dependencies.

**Cons:**
- Need to wait for release cycle or push for patch release to get fixes upstreamed.
- Need to wait for release cycles to commit changes for latest features from `react-native`.

If we are not going to track against a specific version of `react-native`, and instead want to track against the master branch, then we'll need to define our cadence for updating to the latest commits from the `react-native` master branch.

title: WebView blocks gesture responder system
Show console.error as dismiss-able red-box, same as other platforms
body:
Affects dev mode. 
We redirect "soft exceptions" to a red box too. Added a "Dismiss" button as well.

title: React native bundler error
body:
### Environment

<!--
  Please fill in all the relevant fields by running these commands in terminal.
-->

1. `react-native -v`:
react-native-cli: 2.0.1
react-native: 0.44.3

2. `npm ls rnpm-plugin-windows`:

3. `npm ls react-native-windows`:
 react-native-windows@0.44.0-rc.3
4. `node -v`:
v8.9.4

5. `npm -v`:
5.3.0

6. `yarn --version`<!-- (if you use Yarn) -->:
1.3.2
Then, specify:



<!-- (What platform are you building for? Choose any from UWP, WPF) -->
- Target Platform:
WPF

<!-- (What framework version are you building for? Choose from 10.0.14393, 10.0.10586, 10.0.10240, etc. (UWP), .NET 4.6.1, .NET 4.5, etc. (WPF) -->
- Target Platform Version(s):
.NER 4.5
<!-- (What device(s) are you targeting? Choose any from Desktop, Mobile (ARM), Mobile Emulator, Xbox, Hololens) -->
- Target Device(s):
Desktop
<!-- Which operating system are you using? Specify macOS, Windows, or Linux, along with specific release versions -->
- Development Operating System:
Win10

<!-- Which version of Visual Studio are you using? Specify Visual Studio 2015 or Visual Studio 2017 -->
- Visual Studio Version:
VS 2015

### Steps to Reproduce

<!--
  How would you describe your issue to someone who doesnt know you or your project?
  Try to write a sequence of steps that anybody can repeat to see the issue.
  Be specific! If the bug cannot be reproduced, your issue may be closed.
-->

I have been using react-native 0.42 version, and everything was working fine, and then I changed to 0.44, and tried to create release bundle for my windows app using Command

react-native bundle --platform windows --dev false --entry-file index.windows.js --bundle-output windows/app/ReactAssets/index.windows.bundle --assets-dest windows/app/ ReactAssets/


and I get following error:-


Unable to resolve module `AccessibilityInfo` from `C:\Users\<username>\<project>\node_modules\react-native\Libraries\react-native\react-native-implementation.js`: Module does not exist in the module map


This might be related to https://github.com/facebook/react-native/issues/4968

To resolve try the following:

  1. Clear watchman watches: `watchman watch-del-all`.

  2. Delete the `node_modules` folder: `rm -rf node_modules && npm install`.

  3. Reset Metro Bundler cache: `rm -rf $TMPDIR/react-*` or `npm start -- --reset-cache`.  4. Remove haste cache: `rm -rf $TMPDIR/haste-map-react-native-packager-*`.

because of some reason packager is not able to find `AccessibilityInfo` component present in RNW libraries, but I can see component is present at `project\node_modules\react-native-windows\Libraries\Components\AccessibilityInfo`

<!--
  How did you expect your project to behave?
  Its fine if youre not sure your understanding is correct.
  Just write down what you thought would happen.
-->


<!--
  Did something go wrong?
  Is something broken, or not behaving as you expected?
  Describe this section in detail, and attach screenshots if possible.
  Don't just say "it doesn't work"!
-->

<!--
  Please share a project that reproduces the issue.
  There are two ways to do it:

    * Create a new app using https://snack.expo.io/ and try to reproduce the issue in it.
      This is useful if you roughly know where the problem is, or cant share the real code.

    * Or, copy your app and remove things until youre left with the minimal reproducible demo.
      This is useful for finding the root cause. You may then optionally create a Snack.

  This is a good guide to creating bug demos: https://stackoverflow.com/help/mcve
  Once youre done, copy and paste the link to the Snack or a public GitHub repository below:
-->
(Paste the link to an example project and exact instructions to reproduce the issue.)

<!--
  What happens if you skip this step?

  Someone will read your bug report, and maybe will be able to help you,
  but its unlikely that it will get much attention from the team. Eventually,
  the issue will likely get closed in favor of issues that have reproducible demos.

  Please remember that:

    * Issues without reproducible demos have a very low priority.
    * The person fixing the bug would have to do that anyway. Please be respectful of their time.
    * You might figure out the issues yourself as you work on extracting it.

  Thanks for helping us help you!
-->

title: Allow custom shadow nodes to override removal of children
body:
* When there are extra steps that need to be taken to unbind from unsafe/native resources, a ShadowNode has to override the Remove*Children*() methods. This allows users to do that without in-tree modifications.

Thanks to my colleague @shmax for identifying this improvement while developing custom controls.

title: Fix crash where TextInput Width or Height = NaN
body: Fixes issue #1673 by preventing invalid dimensions being passed to MinWidth, or MinHeight, or base.SetDimensions

title: Add explanation about how to import pfx file in another PC
body: Add a sentence to explain how to import `<AppName>_TemporaryKey.pfx` in another PC.

title: Adapt readme to reflect WPF support in the headline
body:
Even so the framework allows to develop WPF applications, only UWP is mentioned in the title. 

Only if you read further in the readme you can notice that it works with WPF, too.

I think it would be a good idea to state the possibility in the headline to reduce some confusions.

title: Fix/workaround a crash when ReactInstance is disposed while AsyncStorage still doing work
body:
Fix/workaround a race that occurs when the tReactInstance has been disposed on another thread while the AsyncStorage mutex is held. Thanks to my colleagues for finding this and providing a fix.


The unit test I added doesn't quite do what I want, since there's no way to synchronize without a callback. I can remove it if no one has a better idea.

I can propagate the fix to UWP if the approach is agreeable.
